column2: With the ongoing growth of our country's population and the continuing struggle to claim new lands in the center of the continent, the question has arisen of how to deal with the native Arcadian tribes in our country. Some have proposed that the natives be confined into autonomous Reservations, while others have argued that the natives be encouraged to adopt our ways and conform in our society. Finally, some have asked  if it would be possible to accept the native cultures as part of a plurinational state.

Since the conquest of the Six Nations in 1828, and the subsequent establishment of the Republic of Carolina within our Union, a large number of the Iroquois have fled into the Great Lakes region. Now, it has become apparent that the remaining Iroquois are planning to join their kin further west. How should we respond?

Although some questioned the wisdom of our policy of integrating the natives cultures into our society, it has become clear in recent years that this policy has paid off. There can be no question that the native peoples are fully part of our state.
